text: hello and welcome to the amazon web services partner webinar series
our topic today features mobile and enterprise apps and api on the aws cloud
i'm your host jerry sullivan i'm with partner marketing team here in seattle and i'd like to welcome you today
we'll start with just a couple housekeeping items before we get going so i'd like to remind folks that we do
record today's session and we do make our presentation materials available on the aws slideshare as well as youtube
channels i'd also like to remind folks that
there is a q a web part in your browser and please feel free to submit questions
anytime during this webcast and we'll take a few moments at the close to address your questions
and be assured that if we don't get to them during the webcast we will follow up with you directly afterwards
i'd like to let you know that today we'll be covering an overview of amazon web services as well as security models
aws identity and access management otherwise known as iam and
we will then jump into intel sharing an overview of api development approach a
use case and a free trial offering and again closing with q a i'm pleased to be joined today by travis
broughton who is the enterprise architect at intel along with ryan holland who is one of our ecosystem
solution architects here at amazon web services with that i'd like to turn it over to
you ryan to take it away thank you very much sherry and thank you everyone for joining us today
so i wanted to start with a quick high-level overview of what aws is as a
platform so a lot of folks might be familiar with ec2 or s3 a lot
of our compute and storage services but it's really a platform that has a
whole host of services that surround our core compute database and storage
these services span from application services to help customers deploy applications in the cloud or to
manage or monitor those applications as well as some very important networking and security services
as well as services that handle identity and access management as well as monitoring
and all of these services are available on top of our global infrastructure
and they're used as building blocks for customers to build their applications on top of these services
so i i spoke about the global infrastructure that all of these are sitting on top of
and it really is a very big and large global footprint as you can see our our
global footprint spans five different continents and it is comprised of nine different
regions and that's a somewhat specific term for aws so what we mean by a region
is a collection of highly redundant data centers that are in a particular
geographic area and we refer to these data centers as availability zones and these are
availability zones are where customers will launch their applications and store their data
and those are all designed to be fault boundaries such that any kind of failure within one availability zone
won't affect any of the other availability zones within a region and we have been growing this global
footprint over the past years and you will continue to see expansion of this footprint as we add additional capacity
to our existing regions as well as add additional regions across the globe
to meet the needs of our customers so i want to talk about a little bit why
customers are moving their workloads to aws and in general we see five
value propositions that customers are attracted to the first one trading capital costs for
operational expenses and lowering your overall cost of ownership for a
particular service or for some servers or storage is typically one of the first things
that customers see value in but as they start to get more familiar with our
platform and they start to to use our services a lot of times we see customers really getting a ton of value out of our
flexibility and the ability to not have to guess on capacity going forward
so the nature of our platform allows you to create storage or compute resources
in seconds versus weeks or months in a traditional data center and it also very importantly allows you
to tear those resources down and and stop paying for them if that particular
resource is no longer necessary so this gives folks the ability to very quickly get new initiatives out to the market
and to try in different initiatives and have very low cost for failure as well and you don't have to guess in big
projections for multiple years about how much storage or compute that particular service is going to need you can grow
your infrastructure as the number of customers that are using that service grows and then lastly the ability to go global
in minutes so i just talked about our global footprint for all of our data centers and this allows you to place
your application or your resources close to where your customers are so if you
want to expand to a new region you don't have to now go and purchase data center space
or buy an office in that particular country you can leverage our global footprint to move your application close
to your customers so now that we've talked at the high level
i want to talk a little bit about security so the the topic of this webinar is enterprise and mobile
applications and apis and so i wanted to start off and describe our security
model and then talk about how we manage api access to our platform
so when we look at security on aws it's a shared responsibility model and what
we mean by that is there's going to be certain parts of the the overall deployment that we're
responsible for securing and this will be the infrastructure so everything from the physical building itself all the way
up through the virtualization layer is going to be the responsibility of aws to
manage and to secure and we go to great lengths to do that that is by far our number one priority and we go through a
very long list of different certifications and audits um on our processes for that as well
security of the applications itself though everything of really an operating system and up
is completely in the control of our customers and so it's your responsibility to secure your
applications and secure your operating systems but this is also where our partner
ecosystem comes into play to help provide you tools and and applications to help you
secure those those assets and then lastly at the bottom we have some security services that are features
or functionalities of our different services that customers can leverage
to enhance their security posture and on the topic of apis i wanted to talk about identity access management
and specifically how we manage access to apis in our
infrastructure so we have a service called iam or identity access management which is what
is used to create and control great user identities or create api keys
and then also create policies and control which users or applications are allowed
to access which of our infrastructure apis and so with iam i can create multiple
users and i can group those in groups and i can create specific policies around what each of
those users or groups can do which api calls to our infrastructure they can make but it's important to draw
the distinction that this really is only for creating and controlling access to our
apis so apis for the aws infrastructure and as we if you start looking at apis
that your application is exposing that's where partner solutions like the intel expressway
express gateway will come into play so we look at how we can extend this to
mobile users we have another service that's part of iam called our security tokens service
that allows you to create temporary security credentials and this is extremely useful for
very large deployments or where you're going to have mobile or browser-based applications that need to interface with
the underlying infrastructure and this allows you to on the fly create a
short-lived set of api credentials that you can pass back to that mobile application or that
enterprise application and give them a very specific set of apis that they're allowed to leverage on
our infrastructure so from a diagram how this would work if i had a
mobile application or a pool of users that need to access something through a browser and i want
to give them access to the aws service api so this would be something again that's modifying
the set of resources that you're running in aws maybe uploading or creating a new object in s3
or starting or terminating an instance in ec2 these are all examples of aws
service apis and you can do that by authenticating from the mobile application to your session proxy or
your authentication store which will leverage our security token service to create a
short-lived very specific set of api keys that can be passed back to that mobile device and then they can
interface with the apis for our services now if the api that you're looking to
control or to provide security for lives in the application that you're running
then that's where again our partner ecosystem would come into play and solutions
such as that from intel will be very appropriate so with that i'll hand over now
to the folks at intel to talk about the intel expressway api manager

architect in intel's data center software division and i'll be talking about
uh as ryan said taking uh your own apis and exposing them through
the amazon web services cloud and and making them uh secure and integrating

so um apis are are a fairly uh hot trend right
now in [Music] in enterprise architecture there's a lot
of enterprises adopting apis as a way to provide
higher availability scalability and resiliency for their apps as they move
to the cloud and and to provide better access for handheld and mobile devices the
the growth in bring your own device and other types of mobile access
drivers from from enterprise are really causing
people to rethink how they deliver applications and whether they're being delivered as as monolithic applications
within the data within the enterprise data center or whether they're being delivered uh through apis that could be
consumed from a number of different locations and from a number of different platforms
so really uh the the other benefit to apis is that they they turn the
enterprise into a platform and and by that i mean they they take uh data and services and
other assets that have historically been locked up inside the corporate firewall and they expose them
in a way that they can be consumed by different devices and and by partner
developers or or other developers uh and there that provides an opportunity for
the enterprise to monetize some of those data and services it extends to reach and you see
companies basically taking uh what was previously just some internal uh secret
sauce and and exposing that in a way that it can be consumed by other developers and charging a fee for that
so the api is becoming a product but if you're offering that up as a product and
a sas model you need to secure it you need to make sure that you manage the sla and you you may have different uh
pieces of information that you want to integrate together to to deliver that
that api as a product so according to programmable web there
are over 9000 public apis and then behind that there are an unknown number
probably much higher in in private apis i know from my experience in intel it
intel has its cloud services platform we have a few other apis that we expose publicly for
developers that that we advertise through a a portal we have a tremendous number
of internal apis a lot of that legacy soap and other
protocols that are internal web services that that are used
to to run our business rest however is becoming dominant and if you want to
surface apis in a way that they can be consumed by by mobile devices or by partners
rest and json as the model that that they expect so there's a
growth there we also see from reading various analyst reports from
gartner forester and others i think the stat of 75 of uh fortune 1000 comes from gartner uh
75 of of fortune 1000 companies will offer one or more public apis in the
next year or so and we're also seeing as a result of companies moving to
virtual private clouds and moving to hybrid cloud usage models as well as companies that are just going
all in and going to the the public cloud we're seeing a lot more integration
flows that extend outside of the enterprise firewall so data services are are being integrated
internally and externally outside of the company and and that's driving some
increased cost in integrating uh those data and delivering them in a a
consistent way that's that's usable by employees and and usable by
partners usable as a as a product
the other driver or another driver for for the growth of of apis
primarily private apis is again the move to the cloud so as
companies move their their legacy applications to the cloud to be
able to uh gain some of the benefits in terms of uh cost and agility and uh
performance that that come from hosting in the cloud
taking a a a service or taking an application and
just dropping it in in place as it was in your on-prem data center to
to the cloud is is not the best practice so from reading uh what the open data
center alliance recommends and and what uh some of my colleagues at intel it uh
recommend uh there's there's really a need to re-architect apps as as they move to the
cloud in inside your on-premise data center you you can effectively uh gold plate
your infrastructure you can deliver a you can invest in a very
uh high performance and and very high reliability uh individual nodes and you
can take and put in redundant power supplies and redundant
disks and and that's a very costly infrastructure investment in order to
deliver high availability for these uh mission critical apps what we're seeing in the
cloud is going the other way which is to move the responsibility for
availability and and for security to the application itself so instead of
depending on a firewall to keep everything out and depending on
a server that that cost fifty thousand dollars to uh to build because it's got
uh raid one and uh mirrored disks uh for
uh for redundancy uh failover power supplies and all that sort of stuff
we're going with lower cost commodity types of servers but deploying
multiple instances of each component of the application and so applications are
being decomposed into uh sets of services and and and those
things are are more loosely coupled and then as those services are deployed one
of the other benefits is that scale can be delivered where it's needed so instead of trying to take this sort of
scale up architecture where if you think you're going to have peak demand you you
size your server for that peak demand and and you deploy 64 gigs of ram if
that's necessary and and 32 cpus if that's necessary you deploy just a
number of different instances and you can scale up and down as as necessary for each of those
components now the way that you take those loosely coupled components and and compose recompose them together
to deliver an application is through apis each of those different modules
generally will talk to each other uh through apis through web services through a restful interface and so that
that is driving uh some some significant growth in the number of apis that we're seeing deployed and again these are
largely private apis internally but then to talk to the client and to connect
back to enterprises or partners there will then be some external facing apis as well
so as an example architecture from the open data center alliance here are a couple of sort of reference
architectures from them on on the left we have a a single app that's that's
decomposed into some different some different modules that all
use apis to communicate with each other so you they they use infrastructure as a service or
platform as a service to deliver sort of the the classic logic tier
then an api is used to connect to a persistent steer tier whether that's
a table a database an object store like like amazon's s3 or a table store like
dynamodb or one of the other amazon database services and then uh
potentially integrating other third-party sas offerings through apis whether
that's for authentication or social posting or some other integration
of capabilities for basically off-the-shelf out-of-the-box functionality that that gets added in through
additional api calls and then on the right we have a
a lot a more of a deployment architecture there where we've got the services deployed
and and multiple instances of of each service and externally facing we have some some
apis that are used load balance to con for the client to connect in and then internal inside the
cloud and or inside the data center we have additional apis that are used to uh
to provide functionality or or persistence for the for the services that
that the client is talking to so some some indirection there and and some additional ability to scale
independently so if one of the services is more active than the other it can be scaled up independently and that helps
control cost and then it can be scaled back down when it when the demand has passed
so as i mentioned uh with the with the last slide the

to provide a a single interface that that's orchestrating uh

types of injection and security types of of risks and attacks and and basically
